Transcription for 833841

Mae y 20 o November 2014. Mae'n enw i'n Catherine James a dwi'n arfer arfer arfer ar gyfer mynd i Joseph Herman,
y prosiect sy'n cymryd yn ymwneud â'r Cymru Ffondad Joseph Herman a Tate Britain,
ymwneud â'r arfer ar gyfer transformio'r tate Britain.
Ydw i yw Will Cull Rosa, a oedd y Trwstiau o'r Ffondad Joseph Herman Cymru.
Rydyn ni wedi'i gweithio ar ein holl ym Mhob, ac rydym yn ymwneud â'r ffyrdd a'r amser Joseph Herman yn Ystradgynlais.
Felly, Caryl, rydych chi'n cael ei gael yn Ystradgynlais.
Rydw i'n cael ei gael, yn wir. Rydw i'n nifer yn Slyverra, ond wedi'i cael ei gael yn Ystradgynlais.
Rydw i'n ffortunol i gael Joseph Herman a'i ffyrdd Catriona mewn ymwneud â'r ymwneud â'r ymwneud â'r Ystradgynlais.
Rydw i ddim gwybod yn y tîm ymwneud â'i cael ei gael yn Ystradgynlais, oherwydd roeddwn i'n unrhyw ffrind.
Ond pan oeddwn i wedi'i ddweud yn 1946 neu 1947, roeddwn i wedi'i ddweud yn gynnyddio 10.
A roedd fy môr a ffrindiaid yn ffrindiaid o Joseph Herman a'i ffyrdd Catriona, a roedd fy môr yn ffyrdd i'n ffyrdd i Catriona.
Catriona roedd yn dda iawn, a rwy'n credu bod, gydag Catriona, Joseph ddim wedi bod yn ffyrdd fel y gallai, oherwydd pan oedd yn ymwneud â'r ymwneud â'r ymwneud â'r Ystradgynlais, roedd yn dda iawn.
Rwy'n credu bod yn rhaid i ni ddweud y stori o sut roedd yn cael ei gael i Ystradgynlais oherwydd roedd hynny wedi bod yn cael ei ffyrdd.
Felly rwy'n siarad am fy mhwyd â nhw a phamau i'w ffyrdd.
Felly, roedd fy môr wedi gweld at y ddau, a pan oedd hi'n gweithio yn y ddau, a roedd Catriona a Joseph wedi bod yn ystod, efallai, ar ddau rhywbeth,
roedd fy môr wedi gweld at y ddau ac yn gwneud yn siwr bod nhw'n ffyrdd a'i edrych arno.
Roedd fy môr a fi'n ffortunol cysylltu â phamau i fy môr pan oedd yn mynd i'r ddau, a roeddwn yn gweithio llawer o gydag fy hun,
yn gwybod y ddau o ddau o ddau dechrau a'i ddau, a'i edrych ar gydag ei gwaith, a'i gwybod ar y bwc, a'r hyn a'r hyn.
Ac pan roedd Joseph wedi gwneud y pwnt o'r festyfil o Bryddain o'r 6 ddau, roedd y canfysau'n bach, a joseph yn mann iawn,
felly roedd hi'n gweithio i fy fath o'n ddau i gweithio'r canfysau'n bach.
Felly roeddwn ni'n gwybod yn fwy o'r ddau, ein ffamiliau, a llawer o ddau yn dod i'r ddau, wrth gwrs, o ddau London a phan o'r ddau ymlaen.
Ac pan oedd y ddau oedd gweithio, mae fy mwyr a phan oedd a fy mwyr a ddau a ddau a dydw i'n ddweud i fynd yno i gael gweithio neu rhywbeth fel hyn.
Ac roeddwn ni'n cael swareth yn ddiweddar, ac roedd Wil Roberts yn dod i'n ddau'i ffielin, a roeddwn ni'n cael swareth, a roeddwn i'n canu, a'r fath o'n canu, a roeddwn i'n canu piano ar y ffiddle.
Ac roedd roedd yn dda iawn yn gwych iawn, a roeddwn i fel peth o'n ffyniad, er enghraifft.
Roeddwn ni'n cael ei wneud yn ddod i'r ffyniad, ond ar y peth o'r ffyniad, dwi ddim yn credu bod y ffyniad oedd unig.
Felly, Catriona wedi gwneud yr holl ddraenau, ac yn dda, mae'r bobl wedi newid y ddwylo fel y caravet, ac roedd y cofnod yn yno, a'n gwasgwyl, a'r sefydliad i'w gysylltu.
A Catriona, fy môr a fy môr, byddwn yn mynd i'r car a chyfrifennu o bichnigau ar y byd, neu i'r byd, ac roeddwn ni'n cael llawer o ffyniad.
Roeddwn ni'n fwy fwych, ac roedd fy môr yn fwy fwych, felly roeddodd nhw'n cael llawer o ffyniad, ond roeddwn ni'n cael llawer o ffyniad.
A Catriona, rwy'n dechrau, wrth gwrs. Joseph ddim yn cael llawer o ffyniad gyda'r bobl.
Yn ogystal â'r bobl, mae'n bwysig, rwy'n credu, bod yn cael ei gael yn un pwp ffactor, yn un pwp ffactor, yn yr ymddygiad yma, a'r hyn yma, ym Mhryddau Gough, a'r hyn yma yw'r ymddiriedd.
A fy ffrind a'i broedd, Evan, yn cael y brif, ond roedd y brif yn cael y gynllun, ond fy ffrind a'i broedd yn cael y gynllun.
Ar beth sy'n cael y жwb yma, oedd yr uchaf o gymysgd JUSTUF mental, lle o n eliadgyfrwng bwerddammu er mherdd.

Joseph did not flee Poland.

because at that time, don't forget, no one had invaded Poland.

at the thought of having lost all his family.

And you know, that's a lot of losing three young people in your life.
I mean, I still can't get over the fact that my brother died when he was 25.
I still remember him every day of my life.
So, you know, when you lose a child, it must be soul destroying in a way.

So did the community of Ystradig yn Llais bring him solace with the chapel, with people, just the everyday life of Ystradig yn Llais?
I think what he appreciated so much in Ystradig yn Llais was first he was accepted.
He was accepted as one of the community.
Everybody thought of him affectionately.
They all talked to him.
They all had the time of day for him.
He felt loved and wanted.
And he says that somewhere, that he was so touched that they accepted him as he was.
And I think that helped him enormously too.
Because, you know, living in London, as they were before they came to Ystradig yn Llais,
he must have felt terribly isolated in a sense.
But to come to this loving, caring community must have been like someone putting a nice big Welsh shawl round him and kuching up to him.
So, yeah, I think that is what he also appreciated, having come to live in Ystradig yn Llais.
And one question I'd like to ask.
What was the feeling that there was going to be a change at the time when Joseph was living in Ystradig yn Llais?
Like you said, were things changing in the area, in the world post-war?
The men were down the mines, but like you said, they wanted their children to go out to get careers,
to do better. Was there a sort of feeling of a new dawn?
That I don't know because I was too young to understand and appreciate things like that. I don't know.
What you must remember, the reason why they both left Ystradig yn Llais was because they were having a divorce.
So what mattered to them was getting out of the place and starting another life.
I mean, you know, Catriona dragged her feet for many years.
She didn't want to have a divorce because she loved Joseph very much.
She didn't want to have a divorce. She didn't even want to not live with him.
It was his choice.
And then, of course, when he met this other woman,
and he said that he fell in love with her.
That was really all that concerned them.
I don't think they left the community with nothing to do with a new dawn as such.
But was there a change of footing in Ystradig yn Llais generally at the time?
Well, I don't know. I mean, you know, when he left in 1955, I left Ystradig in 1956 to go to London.
So obviously, we were all then having opportunities to go away and have an education.
So obviously, things were changing and have changed.
I couldn't go back to Ystradig yn Llais to live now.
There is nothing there for me in that cultural sense of the years when I lived there.
When you left Ystradig yn Llais, we were just about to go off to university.
Well, yeah, I went to the Royal Academy of Music in London.
So as you left Ystradig yn Llais, what was it like as a town before you left Ystradig yn Llais?
Well, it was only a village then. Now it's become a town, but it was only a village then.
It was just our warm community.
At first, when I went to London, I was heartbroken. I was terribly homesick.
The hierith was so strong.
So I used to come home quite often, much to my father's shangha.
He said, if you come home a few more times, you won't be going back up to London.
So I thought, oh gosh, I don't want to stay in Ystradig yn Llais then.
And then he complained later on in life that I wasn't coming down to Ystradig yn Llais often enough.
So you never can please your parents, can you?
Yeah, no, once I left really and got my feet down on the ground and started to live as an adult,
there was no way that I wanted to come back to Ystradig yn Llais to live.
You said about Joseph and Katriona moving away as they were getting a divorce.
What was their relationship like through your eyes when you knew them in Ystradig?
Well, they were just a loving couple, a very artistic couple, different to my parents.
Totally different. Their lifestyle was different.
Don't forget, we were a strong mining community. We all lived in the same way.
We all played in the streets as children. We all went up in the woods and played all day.
We were very safe. And there were no cars around.
Only horses and carts, which is strange to say now.
No, they were just eccentric, strange couple, which I thought were fun and great to be in the company.
They fascinated me.
And your mother got on very well.
Oh, well, my father got on well to them.
But you know, it was difficult for my father. He was a coal miner, earning a very hard living.
And there was this man going out and drawing.
So I think quite perhaps under his breath he said, what's this man doing? Doesn't he go to work, I guess?
So their life was totally different to anything we knew.
It was just free and easy life. They went away a lot. They went to the continent.
Today people can go anywhere. Anybody can go anywhere these days.
They can fly here, fly there. There was no such thing in our day.
But they did. Of course, Katriona drove. Joseph didn't drive.
She drove to France. She drove to Belgium.
They went to Spain. They went to Italy. They went to Greece.
It was unheard of in our day of mining families going off. We couldn't afford it.
It gave you that aspiration for something different.
Yes, a different world totally.
There were celebrities in the way in our area.
Yes, happy times.
As a final lasting memory of that time in your youth with the artist Joseph Herman living round the corner with his wife,
how would you sum it up?
For me, first of all, an extreme privilege for having met and being in contact and lived with, if you like, this couple
who have had a tremendous influence on my life, culturally, intellectually, artistically.
The only thing I can say is that it was an enormous privilege.
The effect that it's had on my own life and career has been enormous.
So much so that now I can live my life the way that I want to live it,
with those two little bubbles at the back of my head.
It's because of them that I learn so much about art and sculpture
that without them I don't think I would have known, I would have been acquainted with.
It has made me so interested and so keen to learn more.
I continue to learn about painters and sculptors and the state of art at the moment in the world
and where we are going and what people are doing.
Because of them, I regularly go to exhibitions all over Europe.
I go to London regularly to see exhibitions.
I read avidly about artists as such.
I've become a sculptor myself and I show my own work and I'm very fortunate that I can sell my work.
I think that it's because of all that time, of that time when I was like a sponge taking it all in
and now having put it into the fruition stage of where I can now do things because of that time.
Fantastic, thank you Carol.

Oedd hwnna'n absolutely fantastic.
